author: ralexstokes
content: so payment proofs are a bit tricky to get right, see some relevant discussion here: https://collective.flashbots.net/t/block-scoring-for-mev-boost-relays/202/19

author: ralexstokes
content: there is no way for mev-boost to query the post-state of the block as it is blinded wrt validator until they have already purchased the block

author: ralexstokes
content: we could include some balance proof against the post-state root in the execution payload header and include this as a "payment proof" in the mev-boost bid

author: pawandhananjay
content:
I wasn't referring to payment proofs. afaiu, it would take some time to implement correctly. 
My worry currently is that a builder that underpays might not get caught unless we are carefully looking at logs for every proposal
I was thinking more of a stop gap solution where we check the fee_recipient balance after the block has already been proposed and compare it to the bid value received during the builder flow. If it's not the same, we send an alert to some monitoring service. The proposer would get scammed for that block, but the community could blacklist that particular builder/relay. Seems like a decent deterrent for builders to avoid underpaying

author: ralexstokes
content: the idea is that relays are validating payments, and if we learned that relays were cheating the system somehow, they would lose a lot/all of their reputational capital

author: ralexstokes
content: even w/ the stop gap, we have to account for interactions w/ the fee_recipient address in the block, e.g. a proposer could also want to send ETH in the same block they propose, but this should not count against the builder

author: ralexstokes
content: i had started work along these lines w/ this relay monitor project:  https://github.com/ralexstokes/relay-monitor and i hear metrika uses some of it to power their relay monitor: https://app.metrika.co/ethereum/dashboard/mev/relay-overview?tr=1d

author: ralexstokes
content: but ultimately the mev-boost eco has evolved to a place where there are a set of well-known relays and so we can really lean on the reputational bit as a community

author: ralexstokes
content: all together, it seems a better use of time currently to focus on ePBS efforts rather than try to add these bells and whistles to police relays

author: ralexstokes
content: of course, this could change in a moment's notice / there is always risk one of the relays could rug the system
